docs.lead_paragraph: For many Americans, December is a month for compulsory shopping sprees, with the urgency escalating as Christmas approaches. But for Olivia Hewitt, the seasonal panic goes beyond choosing between a Furby (if she could find one) or a Barbie for her niece. Instead she wondered, ''Should I get a fourth pair of glasses, have my teeth cleaned again, do a marathon session with my therapist or try acupuncture?'' Even though Ms. Hewitt, 31, a paralegal from Fremont, Calif., is in perfect health, she faces the odd quandary of having to spend $500 on medical care before the ball drops on New Year's Eve -- or forfeit the money.

headline.main: Popular Tax-Free Health Plans Spark Holiday Rush to Doctors

docs.abstract: More than four million Americans who have Flexible Spending Accounts--tax-free savings set aside by employers for health care expenses not covered by insurance--must use up their totals each year or forfeit them; use-it-or-lose-it rule can lead to unusual spending binges at year's end, often on goods and services people do not need; providers of nonemergency care love program, but some health care advocates say program may not be good for efforts to make health care more accessible to all Americans; flexible spending accounts, created by Congress in 1984, were designed to give workers relief from ever-shrinking health care coverage; health care experts say growth of program has been hampered by employees' fear of losing money at end of year (M)
docs.snippet: For many Americans, December is a month for compulsory shopping sprees, with the urgency escalating as Christmas approaches. But for Olivia Hewitt, the seasonal panic goes beyond choosing between a Furby (if she could find one) or a Barbie for her...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Gov. George E. Pataki's veto of a bill that would have given New York City public hospitals $100 million for treating the uninsured (news article, Dec. 23) shows that he is out of touch with people's needs.
docs.abstract: Dr Ellen F Crain letter, commenting on December 23 article, says New York Gov George E Pataki's veto of bill that would have given New York City public hospitals $100 million for treating uninsured shows he is out of touch with people's needs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Serbian Forces Attack Northern Kosovo Province A sustained assault by Serbian forces in northern Kosovo province ended a tenuous cease-fire, as more than 40 armored vehicles and tanks fought through the day with separatist guerrillas. The attack came after 11 days of combat and assassinations in which, international monitors say, the two sides have shown they do not intend to solve their differences peacefully. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Freeze in California Decimates Citrus Crop A four-day freeze has destroyed more than a third of California's annual citrus crop, inflicting nearly $500 million in damage and leading to predictions that orange prices would triple. Across California, cold air from the Gulf of Alaska sent temperatures below freezing on Monday, with readings in the high teens and low 20's in the agriculturally rich Central Valley yesterday -- the worst cold spell since a 10-day freeze in 1990. Officials pronounced the lemon crop a near total loss in the valley and said perhaps half the state's orange crop was lost as well. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The finance reports of the presumptive Speaker of the House, Dennis Hastert of Illinois, show that companies interested in the health care legislation he wrote were major contributors to his campaigns. Health professionals, hospitals and pharmaceutical and insurance companies contributed a total of at least $171,455 to Mr. Hastert's 1998 campaign, accounting for nearly $1 of every $5 he raised for his re-election, Federal campaign records show.

headline.main: Health Care Was Catalyst For Donations To Rising Star

docs.abstract: Finance reports of presumptive Speaker of House, Dennis Hastert of Illinois, show that companies interested in health care legislation he wrote were major contributors to his campaigns (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN a quiet village like this, the handwritten sign plastered across the heartbreaking emptiness of the Larchmont Pharmacy had a startling force. ''Goodbye Larchmont,'' the sign in the window began, deceptively playful. ''After 27 years I have finally decided to go fishing.'' But the sign soon revealed the writer's anger.

headline.main: Our Towns; One More Tear In the Fabric Of Village Life

docs.abstract: Larchmont, NY, loses part of its character with the closing of Larchmont Pharmacy, which has been forced out of business after 27 years by the combination of lower fees paid by insurance companies, the boom in mail-order prescriptions and the proliferation of discount drugstore chains like CVS; chains have already swallowed up its independent theater and gym and are threatening its stationery shop, hardware stores, bookstores and coffee shop; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At least 11 states will miss next month's deadline to fix computers used to pay unemployment insurance, but the states are making stopgap arrangements to avoid any interruption of benefits, Federal officials said today. The computer problems with unemployment insurance are similar to those that threaten many Federal and state government programs and business activities of corporations in the next two years, but the effects could come sooner in offices that send checks to unemployed workers.

headline.main: Computer Glitch to Delay Jobless Benefits for Some

docs.abstract: Deputy Labor Sec Kathryn O Higgins says at least 11 states will miss Jan deadline to fix year 2000 problems with computers used to pay unemployment insurance; glitch is more immediate threat in offices that send checks to unemployed because last day of benefit year is recorded when application is received; states are making stopgap arrangements to avoid any interruption of benefits (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill yesterday that sought to give New York City's public hospital system $100 million to help pay for its swelling ranks of uninsured patients. The veto of the bill, which was approved unanimously by the State Legislature in June, was a huge blow to the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which is struggling to come up with a plan to pay for treating uninsured patients.

headline.main: City Hospitals Lose Funds In Pataki Veto

docs.abstract: New York State Gov George Pataki vetoes bill that sought to give New York City's public hospital system $100 million to help pay for swelling ranks of uninsured patients; veto of bill is huge blow to city's Health and Hospitals Corp (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks Mixed, but Prices Of Bonds Fall Sharply Stocks were mixed in fairly light trading, but Treasury prices posted their biggest decline in six weeks, pushed down by a flow of money from bonds to stocks and a selloff of Japanese bonds. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury rose to 5.13 percent.

headline.main: DNA: Bar Code for a Police State?
